poem:
"An Election Ballad"

A busted flush, Sunak's reign, defiant,
An asylum seeker's dare, compliant.
£3,000, £150k, the cost:
A life in Rwanda, a life lost?
Bookended by bold decrees,
A Government swaying in the breeze.
While we, the folk, assess the score,
Is it time to call once more,
"At will of people, change the station,
Clear the air - it's time, for elevation."
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Rishi Sunak is a busted flush. It’s time to call an election | Observer editorial Rishi Sunak’s government began last week by triumphantly announcing that a man whose asylum claim had been rejected had volunteered to take up to £3,000 cash in exchange for agreeing to take a commercial flight to Rwanda – plus the provision of housing, food and healthcare there for five years at a cost of £150,000 to the taxpayer. Sunak bookended". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
